title: Ticket #6663: condor_vacate_job -fast leaves starters stuck in Preempting/Vacating
description:
condor_vacate_job -fast leaves the corresponding starters stuck in 'Preempting/Vacating'.

  1. condor_vacate_job issues an ACT_ON_JOBS command to the schedd.
  2. The schedd (correctly) sends a SIGQUIT to the shadow.
  3. Daemon core catches the signal and calls main_shutdown_fast(),
  4. which calls Shadow->shutDown( JOB_NOT_CKPTED ),
  5. which calls evictJob( JOB_NOT_CKPTED ),
  6. which calls cleanUp( jobWantsGracefulRemoval() ) and then DC_Exit() without re-entering the event loop.
  7. The starter tries to tell the shadow that it, as instructed by cleanUp(), evicted the job. It can't (the shadow has already exited), causing it ignore the startd's subsequent SIGTERM, as it's waiting for its job lease to expire.

jobWantsGracefulRemoval() returns true by default (and unless it's otherwise configured or the job specifically says not to).

So one problem is that the shadow doesn't hang around for the starter. It seems like the shadow should either always wait for the starter to call it back or that the starter to stop calling it; the former is much easier. (When the schedd really is trying to shut down quickly, e.g. for an upgrade, and it wants to preserve jobs, it just SIGKILLs the starters.)

The other problem is that the shadow asks the starter to shut down gracefully when it itself is shutting down quickly. I was worried that correcting this would be a semantic change, but the condor_vacate_job man page says that -fast means a hard kill: "If the -fast option is used, the job(s) will be immediately killed, meaning that standard universe jobs will not be allowed to checkpoint, and the job will have to revert to the last checkpoint or start over from the beginning."

So the fix ought to be to (a) wait for the starter to finish shutting down and (b) tell it to shut down the correct way (fast), which has the nice effect of making the wait for (a) shorter.
remarks:
2018-May-01 14:01:03 by tlmiller:
In baseshadow.cpp, in BaseShadow::terminateJob(), around line 618, is a call to cleanUp(). This looks like the three other functions I modified in this patch (BaseShadow::HoldJobAndExit(), BaseShadow::removeJobPre(), and BaseShadow::evictJob()) to wait for the starter to exit, but it's presently unclear to me if this make sense given the possibility of recycling the shadow instead of exiting. It may suffice to set a timer which knows about recycling vs. calling DC_Exit(); it may be that terminateJob(), despite calling cleanUp(), will never actually ask the startd/starter to do anything because it should only be called when the starter has already sent us the job_exit RPC (and exited), and we also therefore have nothing to wait for.

2018-May-02 10:59:44 by tlmiller:
So holdJobAndExit() actually really does need to exit immediately to function properly. The tests pass after reverting that change, but now I'm worried about all of the calls to exitAfterEvictingJob() other than the one in evictJob()....

[Regarding the test results for workspace builds 439657 and 439702.]

2018-May-02 11:14:22 by tlmiller:
Assigned to Jaime for code review because I'm worried about the semantic implications of the changes. I'm sure that the evictJob() changes are OK, since that what I was working on, but I'm not sure what to to in terminateJob() and despite holdJobAndExit() looking a lot like evictJob(), duplicating the change there proved to be a mistake.

Do we think this would need a release note?

2018-May-10 11:59:58 by jfrey:
Code Review

  • If the starter sends a job_exit rpc after a delayed exit, the exit reason from the starter is used instead of the one from the delayed exit.

  • If the starter closes the connection without sending a job_exit rpc after a delayed exit, the shadow waits around for 20 seconds. I saw this happen when a periodic hold triggered during input file transfer.

  • If the starter sends a job_exit rpc after a delayed exit, the full cleanup code in evictJob() is run, even though cleanup code was run before. I saw a case where two evict events were logged.

I will commit code to fix these issues.

2018-May-10 13:23:40 by tlmiller:
Code Review

Changes look good and are simple, but raise the issue of if we should just use remRes->setExitReason() instead of introducing delayedExitReason. I'll think about this some more after HTCondor Week.

2018-May-18 13:27:16 by tlmiller:
See also #6664.

2018-Jun-03 16:29:05 by tlmiller:
Further thoughts:

  • It seems proper for the shadow to have its own idea of the exit reason, independent of the remote resource. In the previous code, this was embedded in the code path and not explicitly part of the state.
  • On the other hand, it appears that remRes has lifetime identical to that of the UniShadow object (and that the checks for it being NULL are only defensive programming), so it should at least be safe to store the reason there.
  • remRes->setExitReason()* has side effects we may not want. This could be coded around, but that seems sketchy.

Over-all, I'm not convinced a change is warranted.
